document.docTitle: The integration of MS-based metabolomics and multivariate data analysis allows for improved quality assessment of Zingiber officinale Roscoe

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The integration of MS-based metabolomics and multivariate data analysis allows for improved quality assessment of Zingiber officinale Roscoe

paragraph.docTitle:
The integration of MS-based metabolomics and multivariate data analysis allows for improved quality assessment of
Zingiber officinale Roscoe

document.paragraph:
Mohamed A. Salem
a, *
, Ahmed Zayed b, c , Saleh Alseekh d, e , Alisdair R. Fernie d, e , Patrick Giavalisco f

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Pharmacognosy, Faculty of Pharmacy, Menoufia University, Gamal Abd El Nasr St., Shibin Elkom, 32511, Menoufia, Egypt

document.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O

subSection.paragraph: Chemometrics Geographical origin
Ginger
Metabolomics
Biosynthesis
Quality assessment
A B S T R A C T
* Corresponding author.

E-mail addresses: mohamed.salem@phrm.menofia.edu.eg (M.A. Salem), ahmed.zayed1@pharm.tanta.edu.eg (A. Zayed), Alseekh@mpimp-golm.mpg.de (S. Alseekh), Fernie@mpimp-golm.mpg.de (A.R. Fernie), giavalisco@age.mpg.de (P. Giavalisco).

Metabolomics have been applied previously to evaluate the effect of geographical origin of the same plant species and to discriminate between the different ginger cultivars ( Ciecierska et al., 2019 ). For instance, ginger samples collected from different geographical origins were discriminated based on gingerols and six other gingerol-related compounds using ultra-performance liquid chromatography equipped with mass spectrometry (UPLC/MS) coupled with chemometrics ( Mais et al., 2018 ; Yudthavorasit et al., 2014 ). Additionally, metabolomic-based approach characterized phenolic metabolites of family Zingiberaceae including ginger collected from Korea and Ethiopia ( Asamenew et al., 2018 ). These previous studies focused on the determination of gingerols and shogaols as markers for quality assessment owing to their commercial availability. However, a comprehensive analysis of other metabolites of ginger has not yet been deeply investigated.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Experimental design for metabolic profiling of fresh ginger rhizomes collected from different geographical sources and the effect of drying.

subSection.paragraph: The current research applied a non-targeted metabolomics approach to analyze different metabolites (e.g., phenolic compounds, lipids, organic acids, amino acids, and other primary metabolites) comprehensively in various crude fractions of fresh and dried ginger. It aimed to discriminate fresh ginger samples collected from different geographical regions based on metabolomics data. Moreover, the influence of the drying process on the metabolites profiles has also been investigated. Primary metabolites, especially amino acids, and intermediates were also investigated to trace the biosynthetic pathway of gingerols, while others as fatty acids and sugar monomers assessed the nutritive value of ginger.

Ginger samples collected from four different ginger-producing countries, i.e. , China , India , Pakistan , and Peru , in addition to lab-dried Peruvian samples were subjected to extraction and analysis ( Fig. 1 ). Representative total ion chromatograms of the analyzed ginger samples from both polar and non-polar fractions either in the positive and negative modes were depicted in Figure S1 and S 2 , respectively. The chromatograms obtained from the analyzed conditions were evaluated and aligned to obtain a data matrix of all tested samples, as presented in Figure S3.

A schematic diagram is presented in Fig. 2 showing the steps for confident compound identification taking [6]-gingerol as an example. The extracted ion chromatograms (EIC) of its protonated adduct was detected at m/z 295.191 [M+H] + with a retention time (RT) of 12.94 min. The predicted molecular formula for this adducts was C 17 H 27 O 4 . The ammoniated [M + NH 4 ] + as well as sodiated [M+Na] + adducts were also detected at the same RT showing m/z 312.217 and 317.173, respectively. A more intense and very prominent peak was detected at m/z 277.180 and RT of 12.94 min represented the loss of water from the protonated adduct [M-H 2 O + H] + . Alongside, a deprotonated adduct at m/z 293.175 [M-H] - was identified in the negative ionization mode eluted at the same RT ( Fig. 3A ). The predicted molecular formula for this adduct was C 17 H 25 O 4 . A deprotonation followed by addition of formic acid [M + FA-H] - at m/z 339.180 was also detected. Searching the molecular formula against common MS databases showed that the formula could be tentatively assigned to [6]-gingerol. Using the information from tandem MS, confirmation of the compound identification was based on detection of the characteristic fragment ions, as illustrated previously in Fig. 2 . The detected adducts and fragments of the same compound showed compatible positive correlation among the tested samples, indicating that they have the same precursor and adding more confidence in the identification as shown in Figure S4 .

Next to the use of the information about the detected adducts and fragmentation pattern in combination with co-elution, the elution profiles of compounds from the same class can be used for their collective identification. For instance, different gingerols showed a systematic retention time shift, according to their chain length on the RP column ( Fig. 3B ). Therefore, the separation was achieved according to their hydrophobic properties. Thus, [6]-gingerol that contains shorter carbon chain was eluted earlier (12.94 min) than [8]- and [10]-gingerol with longer chain length at 13.93 and 14.71 min, respectively. If the identified gingerols were plotted as scatter plots, with monoisotopic mass values on the x -axis and RT on the y-axis, other compounds from the same class can be predicted, as demonstrated in Fig. 3C . Using the same approach, all other metabolites were identified by their retention behavior, accurate mass measurements and MS/MS spectral data ( Table S1 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Schematic diagram showing the steps for confident compound identification. The feature with the retention time of 12.94 min and 295.191 m/z, representing 6-gingerol was selected. Total ion chromatogram (TIC) and extracted ion chromatograms (EIC) were measured by UPLC/MS in the positive ionization mode.

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Metabolites discriminating the analyzed fresh ginger samples

subSection.paragraph: PCA analysis essentially allowed the separation of the analyzed samples based on their geographical closeness of the countries of origin ( Fig. 4A and Table S2). A closer look revealed that the three Asian samples were distinct from Peruvian sample of South America.

Phenylalanine and cinnamic acid are the precursors of [6]-gingerol. They showed similar metabolite pattern among the analyzed samples, as shown in Fig. 5 . These metabolites showed also the lowest abundance in Peruvian and Chinese samples, while the highest were in fresh Indian and Pakistani samples. In contrast, the pattern was reversed in case of [6]-gingerol, [6]-shogaol, hexahydrocurcumin, gingerenone A and gingerenone B. Other gingerols, i.e. , [8]- and [10]-gingerol as well as their methylated derivatives showed similar profiles, showing that the fresh Peruvian ginger was the richest in gingerols ( Fig. 5 and S 6 ). Interestingly, Chinese fresh ginger showed the highest abundance of gingerdiol and acetoxy derivatives ( Figure S6 ).

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Metabolites discriminating the influence of drying ginger samples

subSection.paragraph:
Following the drying of Peruvian samples, PCA analysis essentially allowed the separation of the fresh and dried samples ( Fig. 7A ). Orthogonal projections to latent structures discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA) was applied to determine several markers that are distinct in dry samples ( Fig. 7B and C ). Overall, the top 25 metabolites with a VIP score greater than 1 were considered drying-specific informative metabolite markers ( Fig. 7D ). [6]-shogaol, which is derived from [6]-gingerol, was dramatically increased in dried samples. However, [6]-gingerdiol 5-
O - β
- D- glucopyranoside was not affected by drying process ( Fig. 8 ). A dramatic decrease in lipid classes and other primary metabolites, including xylose, riboflavin, and glutathione, was detected following drying process ( Figure S9 and S10). Similarly, the drying of ginger also led to a decrease in the starch content and the total amino acids pool (Figure S11).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 3. The use of retention time, accurate mass, and co-elution pattern for compound validation. A. Total ion chromatogram (TIC) and extracted ion chromatograms (EIC) of [6]-gingerol measured by UPLC/MS in positive and negative ionization modes. B. Different gingerols within the same class show a retention time pattern according to their chain length. Intra-class variability is shown by XIC in positive ionization mode for the 6, 8 and 10-gingerol. C. Scatter plot representation of different gingerols annotated from the tested samples. The m/z of the loss of water from the protonated adducts is given on the x-axis and the observed RT (min) is given in the y-axis. The plot illustrates how the correlation between elution (RT) and chain length in the annotated gingerols can be used for the prediction of other compounds within the same class.

subSection.paragraph: Since [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol are considered the major bioactive compounds of ginger, different solvents were tested for their efficiency to recover them from fresh ginger samples. To determine their absolute concentration, UPLC/MS/MS analytical method was optimized. [6]-Gingerol and [6]-shogaol eluted at retention time of 3.3- and 4.4-min using RP-UPLC method, respectively. [6]-Gingerol and [6]- shogaol have molecular formulae of C 17 H 26 O 4 and C 17 H 24 O 3 with molar masses of 294.38 and 276.376 g /mol, respectively. By MS analysis, they showed better ionization in positive mode with the molecular ion peak at m / z 295.215 and 277.286, respectively, which were equivalent to protonated adduct (M+H) + , as shown in Table 1 . Additionally, by optimizing the multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) method, each compound showed three characteristic transitions. These fragments were used for qualitative identification, while the intense peaks at m / z 277.2 and 137.2, respectively, were used for absolute quantitative analysis (Figures S12 and S13). Absolute quantification of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol in fresh ginger samples was based on a standard calibration curve with a regression coefficient (R 2 ) of 0.999 within a linear range of 10 μg/mL- 10 ng /mL and 1 μg/mL- 0.1 ng /mL for [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol, respectively (Figure S14).

The result of this analysis showed that acetonitrile and methyl tert - butyl ether (MTBE) were the best solvents for extraction of [6]-gingerol, while isopropanol allowed the best extraction of [6]-shogaol, as shown in Fig. 9 . Since ginger is usually consumed as herbal tea or by adding ginger slices to fresh juices or water, we tested water as solvent for extraction. The results showed that using water also allowed the good extraction of both compounds, without noticeable differences between hot and cold extraction. Although the organic solvents allowed better extraction, the yield did not exceed 1.4-fold increase compared to water extraction. It is noteworthy to observe that the conversion of [6]- gingerol is not spontaneously induced during extraction with hot water.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Multivariate data analysis (MVDA) of fresh Ginger samples collected from different localities. A. Principal component analysis (PCA) showed clear separation of geographically different fresh ginger samples. B. VIP scores showing the top 25 metabolites discriminating ginger samples C. Dendrogram of the investigated fresh ginger samples based on the metabolites obtained after MS data analysis.

subSection.paragraph: Ginger is usually available in different forms such as fresh ginger rhizomes, dried ginger spice or ginger herbal teas. In our study, ginger rhizome samples were collected from four different ginger-producing countries, i.e. , China , India , Pakistan , and Peru . The physical appearance of the collected ginger samples did not allow the discrimination according to the country of origin. Additionally, we subjected the fresh Peruvian ginger sample to laboratory drying which was analyzed to trace drying-induced metabolic changes.

Moreover, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) classifies ginger among “generally recognized as safe” (GRAS) materials or substances ( Kubra and Rao, 2012 ). Identification and quality assessment of ginger is based on few components’ determination, including gingerols, gingerdiones and shogaols contents by simple chromatographic techniques, as TLC and liquid chromatography equipped with UV detector ( You et al., 2019 ). Also, adulteration of ginger powder is rare owing to its characteristic aroma, however, in older literature, various species of
Curcuma
,
Capsicum
, and grains of Paradise (
Amomum melegueta
) may be added to exhausted material in order to enhance color and pungency. Addition of plant starch derived from other species was also reported (USP41, 2018).

In addition, natural climate and geography have been proven to greatly influence plant metabolomes ( Ciecierska et al., 2019 ). Therefore, the ginger samples investigated in this study were collected from different localities to study the effect of geographical distribution on the metabolic content. The physical appearance of the collected ginger samples did not allow the discrimination according to the country of origin. Therefore, phytochemical investigation was required to determine the product quality and discriminate between different geographical origins ( China , India and Pakistan in Asia and Peru in Latin America). Results indicated the geographical origin affecting the primary and secondary metabolites abundances. For instance, the Peruvian ginger in addition to its high content of gingerols and paradols, showed the lowest content of free amino acids, glutathione, and starch either in fresh or lab-dried samples. By contrast, Chinese ginger was characterized by its high content of gingerdiols and their acetoxy derivatives. Furthermore, fresh Peruvian ginger was found to be the richest in most lipids adding a nutritive advantage over the Asian gingers.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. The influence of geographical distribution of ginger on the gingerols and gingerol-related metabolites. The figure also describes the biosynthetic pathway of [6]-gingerol and hexahydrocurcumin and subsequent transformations. The opposed abundances of the precursors ( i.e. , phenylalanine and cinnamic acid) and end products ( i.e. , [6]-gingerol, hexahydrocurcumin, and gingerenone A and B) hypothesize that they have the same biosynthetic pathway.

subSection.paragraph:
PCA analysis is a powerful tool usually used to handle a large amount of data based on multiple variables. It allowed the separation of the analyzed samples based on the geographical closeness of the countries of origin. PCA showed clear separation of geographically different ginger samples. In addition, OPLS-DA showed clear separation of fresh and dried counterparts. Different markers were chosen to justify the differences. Examples include [6]-gingerol, [6]-shogaol, and [6]-gingerdiol 5-
O -β
- D- glucopyranoside. Transformation of [6]-gingerol to [6]-shogaol upon drying was consistent with the previously-reported results showing that dried ginger is more effective and widely-used for therapeutic applications than the fresh counterpart due to high content and abundance of [6]-shogaol ( Jung et al., 2018 ; Ok and Jeong, 2012 ; Saha et al., 2014 ). Interestingly, [6]-shogaol is known for its pharmacological activities as potential antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory even more than gingerols ( Dugasani et al., 2010 ).

Obviously, hot water extraction did not improve the conversion of gingerol and consequently increase in concentration of shogaol. This may be explained by the fact that the heat-induced dehydration of gingerol needs dryness and long exposure to high temperature or storage for a long period in warm conditions. The similar pattern of [6]- gingerdiol 5- β - D- glucopyranoside to [6]-gingerol either in fresh or dried samples confirmed that [6]-gingerdiol 5-β- D- glucopyranoside was not affected and resisted its conversion to other metabolites upon heat drying. The blockage of the dehydration site by the glucose molecule consequently inhibited the heat-induced dehydration step as occurred in [6]-gingerol. Jiang et al. have previously demonstrated that geographical origins of ginger did not affect plant genetics since all cultivated samples were genetically identical ( Jiang et al., 2006 ). Therefore, development of quality control based on chromatographic techniques is essential to guarantee robustness of the used analytical methods. Gingerols, including [6]-, [8]- and [10]-gingerol are responsible for ginger pungent taste. They were specially considered as potential markers for discrimination between the geographically different samples, in addition to the study the effect of drying process on the metabolic profile.

Interestingly, consumption of ginger as a functional food was proven in the current research, where presence of high levels of citric acid added to the value of ginger as nutraceutical since citric acid has been reported to possess neuro-, hepato-, and geno-protective activities (Abdel-Salam et al., 2014). Other acids, such as 2-hydroxy cinnamic acid or O -coumaric acid seemed to be among the heat-induced products and contributed to the antioxidant power of the dried ginger preparations. Additionally, assessment of amino acids and organic acids profiles are important parameters for food and herbal quality control ( Dahl-Lassen et al., 2018 ; Li et al., 2018 ). Among the detected amino acids, valine content was rich in dried than fresh samples in general. This could be explained by the resistance of branched chain amino acids against heat and potentially also the conversion of other branched chain amino acids such as isoleucine to the simplest branched chain amino acid valine. Other primary metabolites such as xylose, riboflavin and glutathione were more abundant in fresh samples than dried products. This also confirmed that fresh samples may be considered a more nutritive source of valuable elements than dried products.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. The influence of geographical distribution of ginger on metabolites content.

subSection.paragraph: The current study has also succeeded to highlight biosynthetic aspects of ginger major metabolites, including gingerol biosynthesis. Previous studies have confirmed that [6]-gingerol is biosynthesized through the phenylpropanoid pathway or specifically shikimate-acetate mixed pathway (Figure S15). Firstly, Denniff, et al. demonstrated that dihydroferulic acid and hexanoic acid were the key intermediates in biosynthesis of [6]-gingerol. However, later Ramirez-Ahumada et al. have proposed an alternative pathway. This study showed that other key intermediates were involved as p -coumaroyl 5- O -shikimate and 1-dehydro-[6]-gingerdione ( Semwal et al., 2015 ). Abundances pattern of phenylalanine and cinnamic acids confirmed that gingerols are biosynthesized via shikimic acid pathway. Moreover, an inverse relationship was observed between the abundance of the [6]-gingerol precursors, i.e. , phenyl alanine and cinnamic acid, and end products, i.e. , [6]-gingerol, gingerenone A, and gingerenone B, especially in fresh samples, where samples with low precursor contents showed high levels of [6]-gingerol. Similarly, hexahydrocurcumin was highly affected by the same precursors and demonstrated to be synthesized also from phenylalanine and cinnamic acid via a side reaction with feruloyl-CoA parallel to biosynthesis of [6]-gingerol. This pathway was also consistent with previous studies ( Jiang et al., 2017 ). However, its conversion to gingerenone A and gingerenone B was not equally produced, especially for the Chinese sample, where conversion to gingerenone B was more favored.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 7. Multivariate data analysis (MVDA) of fresh and dried Peruvian ginger samples. A. Principal component analysis (PCA) showed clear separation of fresh and dried ginger samples. B. Orthogonal projections to latent structures discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA) showed clear separation of fresh and dried ginger samples. C. Splot of OPLS-DA. D. VIP scores based on the metabolite data from fresh and dry ginger extracts.

subSection.paragraph: Application of non-targeted plant metabolomics provided comprehensive data regarding the phytochemical profiles of metabolites of ginger using MS-based metabolomics and chemometrics. It discriminated between ginger samples of different geographical origins and allowed assessment of the drying process. Additionally, the relation between primary metabolites, such as amino acids, i.e. , phenylalanine, and key intermediates of gingerols biosynthetic pathway emphasized the previously reported biosynthetic studies. A single compound is not enough for quality control and moreover the activity of the extract cannot be represented by single compound. Therefore, the applied metabolomic approach can be used in the field of quality control of herbal medicines providing more valuable information than singlecomponent analysis. Moreover, ginger showed richness in amino acids, sugars, organic acids and various lipids supported its use as a nutraceutical. From a nutritive perspective, fresh ginger is better than dried preparations, since it provides essential amino and fatty acids. However, dried ginger preparations are medicinally valuable, due to their higher contents of shogaols and organic phenolic acids. Furthermore, several non-gingerol related compounds were identified which may be promising as drug candidates or in revealing the secrets of the numerous bioactivities of ginger.

Standards of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol were obtained from Sigma Aldrich (Steinheim, Germany ). LC-grade solvents were obtained from Biosolve Chemicals (Biosolve Chimie, Dieuze, France ). Standard solutions ( 1 mg /mL) of [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol for HPLC–MS/MS analysis were prepared individually by dissolving each compound in 50% methanol and then were stored at 20 ◦ C until use.

Fresh ginger (
Zingiber officinale Roscoe
; Zingiberaceae ) rhizome samples, five replicates each, from China (Chinese ginger), India (Indian ginger), Peru (Peruvian ginger), Pakistan (Pakistani ginger) were purchased from BIO COMPANY GmbH ( Berlin , Germany ). All samples were randomized by origin and the fresh ginger samples were peeled with a knife carefully to remove the outer skin without damaging the inner layers. The peeled rhizomes were sliced into small pieces of almost the same thickness and length. The fresh Peruvian sample was chosen as a representative to study the effect of drying. It was cut into slices of 1 mm . Then, the slices were subjected to a tray drying in an oven (BINDER FD Heating ovens, Germany ) adjusted at 40 ◦ C for 1.5 days.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 8. The influence of drying of ginger on the gingerols and gingerol-related metabolites.
Table 1 Optimized multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) transitions for analysis of [6] gingerol and [6]-shogaol in fresh ginger rhizome.

subSection.paragraph: All samples were labeled and then kept frozen in liquid nitrogen until extraction. The initial moisture content of all samples was determined to remove the possible contribution of water content in subsequent determinations. All samples were weighed on an analytical balance (Sartorius, Germany ). They were then either oven-dried for 48 h at 80 ◦ C. After oven-drying, the samples were reweighed. The moisture content of all dried seaweed samples was calculated as follows: Moisture content (%) = [(weight before drying (g)) (weight after drying (g))] × 100 (weight before drying (g)).

heading.emphasis: 4.3. Experimental design, sample extraction and analysis

subSection.paragraph: Ginger samples collected from four different ginger-producing countries, i.e. , China , India , Pakistan , and Peru , were homogenized and the homogenized samples were subjected to extraction ( Salem et al., 2016 ). Briefly, five replicates of 50 mg of each sample were placed in micro-centrifugation tube with pre-cooled (1 mL, 20 ◦ C) MTBE: methanol (MeOH) (3:1, v/v ), vortexed for 1 min followed by incubation on an orbital shaker (100 rpm) for 45 min at 4 ◦ C and then sonicated for 15 min. Additionally, a phase-separating step was conducted afterwards with 650 μL H 2 O/MeOH (3:1, v/v ) followed again with a vortex step for 1 min and centrifugation at 20,000× g for 5 min at 4 ◦ C. The protocol resulted in the appearance of three different phases, including non-polar fraction represented by the MTBE upper layer, polar fraction in the middle MeOH/H 2 O layer, and a precipitated pellet in the lowest layer.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 9. [6]-Gingerol (A) and [6]-shogaol (B) contents in μg/g fresh weight (μg/ g FW) among the tested fresh ginger samples using different extraction solvents. Error bars indicate mean ± SE for five replicates. Black asterisks indicate significance difference from the Peruvian samples (*
P <
0.05, Student’ s t -test).

subSection.paragraph: Afterwards, a fixed volume (500 μL aliquots) of the upper MTBE layer was collected, dried for 3 h, and subjected to lipids analysis using reversed phase (RP) ultra-performance liquid chromatography coupled with Fourier transform tandem mass spectrometry (UPLC-C 8 -FT-MS/ MS). The samples were resuspended in 250 μL acetonitrile:isopropanol (70:30) and 4 μL was injected. In addition, fixed volumes (200 μL and 400 μL aliquots) of the middle MeOH/H 2 O layer were collected, dried for 12 h, and subjected to analysis using GC-TOF-MS and UPLC-C 18 -FT-MS/MS, respectively.

Furthermore, the whole protocol steps were similarly performed for blank samples, where the sample preparation, extraction, and analysis steps were repeated in the absence of plant materials, i.e. , empty extraction tubes. QC samples representing a pool made up of equal amounts of all investigated ginger specimen was also included for quality assessment purposes. QC were analyzed prior to sample acquisition and after every ten samples. They were used to confirm the stability and reproducibility of the analysis.

The upper MTBE layer was analyzed for lipid content by UPLC-C 8 - FT-MS/MS, where the Bridged Ethyl Hybrid (BEH) C 8 column (100 × 2.1 mm containing 1.7 μm diameter particles, Waters®, Manchester , UK ) was equipped with a Waters Acquity UPLC system (Waters®, Manchester , UK ). The mobile phases were composed of buffer A consisted of aqueous 1% ( v/v ) 1 M ammonium acetate in 0.1% ( v/v ) acetic acid, while buffer B consisted of acetonitrile: isopropanol (7:3, v/v ) containing 1% 1 M ammonium acetate in 0.1% acetic acid. The UPLC system was programmed for metabolites separation by gradient elution with a flow rate adjusted at 400 μL/min, The mobile phase composition varied by time to be 45% A for 1 min, 3 min gradient linear from 45% A to 35% A, 8 min linear from 25% A to 11% A, and then 3 min linear from 11% A to 1% A. Afterwards, the column was washed for 3 min with 1% A and then re-equilibrated by setting the mobile phase back to 45% A for 4 min.

UPLC-C 18 -FT-MS/MS consisted of RP-High Strength Silica (HSS) T3 C 18 column (100 × 2.1 mm containing 1.7 μm diameter particles, Waters®), combined with Waters Acquity UPLC system (Waters®, Manchester , UK ) and a mobile phase flow rate at 400 μL/min. The mobile phases of the chromatographic separation were aqueous 0.1% formic acid (buffer A) and methanol containing 0.1% formic acid (buffer B). Linear gradient elution was also applied using 99% A for 1 min, from 99% A to 65% A till 13 min, then 65% A to 30% A till 14.5 min, 30% A to 1% A till 15.5 min, hold at 1% An until the 17 min, and finally to 17.5 min a linear gradient from 1% A to 99% A. The column was re-equilibrated by 99% A for 2.5 min. The UPLC system was coupled with mass spectrometer (MS) worked in positive and negative ionization mode using a heated electrospray ionization (HESI) source together with an Exactive, Orbitrap-type, MS (Exactive, Thermo-Fisher®, Bremen , Germany ).

The instrumentation and chromatographic parameters of GC-TOF-MS were performed as previously described ( Lisec et al., 2006 ). Briefly, aliquots of the polar phase (0.2 mL) were dried down before they were re-suspended in 40 μL of methoxyamine-hydrochloride/pyridine solution followed by heating at 37 ◦ C for 90 min. The samples were further derivatized with 90 μL of N -methyl- N -trimethylsilyltrifloracetamide (MSTFA) for 30 min at 37 ◦ C. One μL of the derivatized sample mixture was injected onto the GC-column and measured.

For protein extraction, the washed pellet remained after metabolite extraction was re-suspended in 150 μL of protein extraction buffer (6 M urea, 2 M thiourea, 15 mM DTT, 2% CHAPS and protease and phosphatase inhibitors). The samples were incubated for 30 min on an orbital shaker (100 rpm) at room temperature and finally centrifuged at 5000× g for 10 min and the protein concentration was determined from the collected supernatant ( Salem et al., 2016 ). For starch extraction, the washed pellet after protein extraction was re-dissolved in 0.5 mL of water and the samples were heated at 100 ◦ C for 1.5 h. The dissolved starch was digested enzymatically using a mix of α -amyloglucosidase and α -amylase, according to manufacturer instructions. Starch concentration was determined based on a calibration curve of a standard glucose ( Salem et al., 2016 ).

For UPLC/MS data, it is often difficult to fully identify compounds without having commercially available authentic standards. Owing to the non-availability of authentic standards for gingerol-related compounds, as well as other ginger metabolites, annotation of the detected metabolite features from UPLC/MS metabolomics approach was based on accurate m/z , retention time, isotope distribution and fragmentation pattern ( Schymanski et al., 2014 ; Sumner et al., 2007 ). The metabolite information was searched against public databases (METLIN, Chem-Spider, KEGG, PubChem, MassBank, HMDB, KNApSAcK, Metabolomics. jp, Metabolomics workbench). Some compounds such as gingerols and shogaols were identified based on comparison with commercially available standards. Metabolite features from positive and negative ionization modes were merged into one dataset (Calder´on-Santiago et al., 2016). Metabolite features that are derived from the same compound were grouped based on 5 ppm tolerance of the mass difference, 0.05 min tolerance of retention time and > 0.9 correlation coefficient between the metabolite features across all the samples. For GC-MS data analysis, chromatograms were exported from Leco® ChromaTOF-GC Software v3.34 to R software (www.r-project.org). Peak detection, retention time alignment and library matching were performed using the Target Search R package ( Cuadros-Inostroza et al., 2009 ).

The chromatograms obtained from the analyzed samples were evaluated and aligned to obtain a data matrix of all tested samples. In addition, metabolite features were grouped according to accurate mass difference, retention time, and correlation between metabolite features across all samples. The data analysis obtained from either UPLC-C 8 -FT-MS/MS or UPLC-C 18 -FT-MS/MS was performed using the Progenesis QI software package (Progenesis QI Version 2.2, Nonlinear Dynamics, Newcastle , UK ). The resulted UPLC or GC matrices were imported into Microsoft Excel (Excel, 2010; Microsoft, Redmond, USA ). Only compounds with at least five-fold higher intensity in comparison to the blank peaks were further considered for analysis. Compounds that showed missing values in more than two of the five biological replicates were excluded. Metabolite data obtained were normalized by weight, followed by using internal standard normalization. All statistical analyses were performed using the algorithms embedded within Microsoft excel. Bar graphs were plotted using either Excel or Sigma Plot 12.5 (http://www.sigmaplot.co.uk).

In addition, MVDA such as principal component analysis (PCA) was conducted to evaluate the obtained results and to exclude outliers. Also, orthogonal projections to latent structures discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA) was applied to determine several markers that are distinct in dried samples. Furthermore, variable importance in the projection (VIP) scores, which is an estimation of the importance of each variable in the projection used PLS-DA. Variables with a VIP score of ≥1 were considered important. VIP scores were extracted for components 1 and 2 since they accounted for about 80% of the total variance. MVDA was performed using SIMCA-P Version 13.0 (Umetrics, Umeå, Sweden ) and Metaboanalyst 3.0 ( Xia et al., 2015 ), following log 2 -transformation and Pareto scaling (centered mean is divided by the square root of the SD of each variable).

To evaluate the absolute [6]-gingerol and [6]-shogaol concentrations in fresh ginger samples, different extraction solvents were applied followed by UPLC/MS/MS analysis. Aliquots ( 50 mg each) of the tested samples were extracted with 1 mL of either; water, 25% MeOH, 50% MeOH, 75% MeOH, 100% MeOH, acetonitrile, ethyl acetate, MTBE, or isopropanol. The hot water extraction was performed by adding the hot water (80 ◦ C) to ginger samples and the extraction was kept at 80 ◦ C for 30 min. For extraction, the samples were vortexed quickly, incubated on an orbital shaker for 30 min, sonicated for 10 min and finally centrifuged at 10,000× g for 10 min. Standard dilution series of [6]-gingerol and [6]- shogaol were prepared in 50% MeOH/H 2 O in the range of 0–10 μg/mL for calibration curve construction.

The samples and standards were separated by a RP-UPLC system ( Waters Acquity UPLC system, Waters ®, Manchester , UK). A high strength silica (HSS) T3 column ( 100 mm × 2.1 mm containing 1.8 μm diameter particles, Waters ®, Manchester , UK ) fitted with 2.1 × 5 mm guard column (ACQUITY UPLC HSS T3 VanGuard Pre-column , 100 Å, 1.8 μm, Waters ®, Manchester , UK) was used. The gradient parameters for RP-UPLC were as follows: 80% eluent A (aqueous 0.1% formic acid) for 6.5 min, 45% B (0.1% formic acid in methanol) from 6.5 to 7 min; 10% A from 7 to 7.1 min, held at 0% A from 7.1 to 8.1 min, returned back to initial the conditions by 8.1 min. Finally , the column was re-equilibrated and conditioned to 80% A from 8.1 to 10 min. The column temperature was set at 40 ◦ C, the flow rate was 0.4 μL/min, the autosampler temperature was set at 10 ◦ C, and the injection volume was 7.5 μL. Moreover , the MS/MS analysis following the UPLC step was achieved using a quadrupole/ linear ion trap (QLIT) mass analyzer (4000 QTRAP, AB Sciex Germany GmbH, Darmstadt , Germany ) in multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) scan type equipped with an electrospray ionization source ( Turbo V ™ Ion Source , AB Sciex ). The operating parameters for MS/MS analysis were as follows: ion polarity; positive, ion source; Turbo spray, capillary ion spray voltage; 5.5 kV, probe tip position; 5 mm , source temperature; 500 ◦ C, carrier gas; nitrogen, curtain gas; 25 psi, nebulizing gas (GS1) and focusing gas (GS2); 40 psi, interface heater. Furthermore , Analyst software (version 1.6.2, AB Sciex ) was used for instrument control next to data acquisition, processing, and analysis (
Salem et al., 2020 a
, 2020b).
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

MAS is supported by the Academy of Scientific Research and Technology (ASRT-Egypt) under the Joint ASRT-BA Research Grants Program (Grant Number: 1044). ARF and SA are supported by the European Union’ s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme, project PlantaSYST (SGA-CSA No. 739582 under FPA No. 664620).
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112843.

M.A.S and P.G. conceived and designed the research. M.A.S performed the experiments. M.A.S, A.Z., S.A. and A.R.F. analyzed the data and performed the statistical analysis. M.A.S., A.Z., A.R.F. and P.G. wrote the manuscript. All the authors read and approved the manuscript after critical revision.
